t: Proverbs 31
Sayings of King Lemuel
The*p sayings of King Lemuel—an inspired utterance his mother taught him.
Listen,*pn my son! Listen, son of my womb! Listen,*ld my son, the answer to my prayers!
Do*ln not spend your strength on women, your*ld vigor on those who ruin kings.
It*pn is not for kings, Lemuel— it*ld is not for kings to drink wine, not*ld for rulers to crave beer,
lest*ln they drink and forget what has been decreed, and*ld deprive all the oppressed of their rights.
Let*ln beer be for those who are perishing, wine*ld for those who are in anguish!
Let*ln them drink and forget their poverty and*ld remember their misery no more.
Speak*pn up for those who cannot speak for themselves, for*ld the rights of all who are destitute.
Speak*ln up and judge fairly; defend*ld the rights of the poor and needy.
Epilogue: The Wife of Noble Character
A*pn wife of noble character who can find? She*ld is worth far more than rubies.
Her*ln husband has full confidence in her and*ld lacks nothing of value.
She*ln brings him good, not harm, all*ld the days of her life.
She*ln selects wool and flax and*ld works with eager hands.
She*ln is like the merchant ships, bringing*ld her food from afar.
She*ln gets up while it is still night; she*ld provides food for her family and*ld portions for her female servants.
She*ln considers a field and buys it; out*ld of her earnings she plants a vineyard.
She*ln sets about her work vigorously; her*ld arms are strong for her tasks.
She*ln sees that her trading is profitable, and*ld her lamp does not go out at night.
In*ln her hand she holds the distaff and*ld grasps the spindle with her fingers.
She*ln opens her arms to the poor and*ld extends her hands to the needy.
When*ln it snows, she has no fear for her household; for*ld all of them are clothed in scarlet.
She*ln makes coverings for her bed; she*ld is clothed in fine linen and purple.
Her*ln husband is respected at the city gate, where*ld he takes his seat among the elders of the land.
She*ln makes linen garments and sells them, and*ld supplies the merchants with sashes.
She*ln is clothed with strength and dignity; she*ld can laugh at the days to come.
She*ln speaks with wisdom, and*ld faithful instruction is on her tongue.
She*ln watches over the affairs of her household and*ld does not eat the bread of idleness.
Her*ln children arise and call her blessed; her*ld husband also, and he praises her:
“Many*ln women do noble things, but*ld you surpass them all.”
Charm*ln is deceptive, and beauty is fleeting; but*ld a woman who fears the Lord*s is to be praised.
Honor*ln her for all that her hands have done, and*ld let her works bring her praise at the city gate.
